content:
re :The first one shows my Firefox screen with the three accounts and their subfolders

That looks like Thunderbird not the browser called Firefox :)

The outlook image looks like the 'Outlook' program and not the webmail account. It's always best to compare with the server aka webmail account.

In Microsoft account - accessed via a browser eg: Firefox - all email addresses are called alias accounts. Is the hotmail email address set up as the 'primary' email address ?

Is the hotmail account in Thunderbird set up as an imap or pop account ? If Imap then check this first:

  • Right click on the hotmail account name folder in Folder Pane and select 'Subscribe'.
  • Click on 'Refresh'
  • Select all the required folders
  • click on 'OK'

Did folders appear ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
In the 'Outlook' program is the hotmail account set up as a Pop account?

In webmail account accessed via browser - are there any emails displaying on server ? If yes, outlook program has hotmail set up as Pop and no emails on server then an Imap account to same email address in Thunderbird is going to look empty as there is nothing to display. You would have to alter that Pop account to 'Leave messages on server'.

Just had a thought..... In the webmail account accessed via a browser have you enabled imap ? If you want to use POP or IMAP to access your email in Outlook.com, you'll first need to enable access.

  • Select Settings > Mail > Forwarding and IMAP.
  • Under POP and IMAP, toggle the slider for Let devices and apps use POP or Let devices and apps use IMAP to ON depending on the account you are enabling.
  • Select Save.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: go to settings and try changing the DNS resolution to DNS over HTTPS. you mention ATT and they have a poisoned DNS that is used to pretend they offer email. the cloudflare DNS use by default with the HTTPS offering does not have that. I have a feeling it is the cause of your issue and it will be quick to try it out.

creator: davidsk

content:
Yes.

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom and click on 'Config Editor' button
  • It open the 'Advanced Preferences' in a new tab
  • In search type: FilterRate
  • Look for: mail.server.default.periodicFilterRateMinutes
  • It will auto say 10
  • Click on the Pencil icon on the right
  • Clear the 10 and type in the new setting eg: 20
  • click on the tick icon to save the setting.

Reopen the Message Filters then either select a filter and click on 'Edit' or click on 'New' You will notice the change eg: 'Periodically, every 20 minutes'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Try this:

  1. exit thunderbird and copy the permissions.sqlite and content-prefs.sqlie files elsewhere
  2. now, restart thunderbird and click to settings>privacy&security and click the exceptions button and adjust as desired for the temporary restrictions
  3. at end of the temporary period, exit thunderbird and copy the backed up files back and then restart thunderbird
creator: davidsk

How about viewing messages in plain text only, instead of HTML? View (Alt-V) - Message Body As - Plain Text

Alternatively 'Simple HTML' may also do what you want, but I haven't tried it.
creator: christ1

content:
christ1 said
How about viewing messages in plain text only, instead of HTML? View (Alt-V) - Message Body As - Plain Text Alternatively 'Simple HTML' may also do what you want, but I haven't tried it.

As far as I can tell, those view modes would still download all the HTML but just not show it to me, making it harder to read without any benefit. I have no idea whether it would still download remote content if the sender is in my pre-approved Exceptions list - that's hard to test because I can't see it.

I do plan to use the Disk Space feature in Account Settings to prevent downloading big messages (I tested it and it works nicely - the message will show content up to the limit you've set and then say "Truncated" with a link to download the rest if desired). That's going to be my main line of defense, as big attachments are worse than remote images like logos. I just thought remote images would be a second area I could limit.
creator: osakawebbie

creator: @next

content:
This is not a problem. if the accounts are POP, you would need to coordinate somewhat, but that would be only concern. If account is IMAP, thee is nothing to be concerned about. If using Windows, these steps will copy to new pc:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, started once and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This WILL prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it 
#   start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
English: Please remember to use English in the Forum. You can use Google Translate to help if your English is not so good.

This really helps because I have a lot of questions or comments to check and I really cannot spend additional time translating everything. Hopefully, you will understand the situation. Thanks.

Thunderbird doesn't control the keyboard. When you use the keyboard, it sends information to the computer, and computer applies it to the active application. Therefore, if the keyboard isn't working, it's not communicating with the computer and can thus appear inactive in Thunderbird. This could be a poor link between keyboard and computer or keyboard not intialised when starting up computer. Check any wires that connect keyboard to computer. Check drivers are up to date. It might occur if computer is waking from hibernation. Unplug keyboard and then try reconnecting.

But these issues you can search on google. But, it's not Thunderbird causing the problem.


Français Merci d’utiliser l’anglais sur le forum. Vous pouvez utiliser Google Traduction si votre anglais n’est pas parfait.

Cela est très utile, car j’ai beaucoup de questions et de commentaires à traiter et je ne peux pas consacrer du temps à tout traduire. J'espère que vous comprendrez la situation. Merci.

Thunderbird ne contrôle pas le clavier. Lorsque vous utilisez le clavier, il envoie des informations à l’ordinateur, qui les applique à l’application active. Par conséquent, si le clavier ne fonctionne pas, il ne communique pas avec l’ordinateur et peut donc apparaître inactif dans Thunderbird. Cela peut être dû à une mauvaise connexion entre le clavier et l’ordinateur, ou au fait que le clavier n’ait pas été initialisé au démarrage de l’ordinateur.

Vérifiez les câbles reliant le clavier à l’ordinateur. Assurez-vous que les pilotes sont à jour. Ce problème peut survenir si l’ordinateur sort de hibernation. Débranchez le clavier, puis rebranchez-le.

Vous pouvez trouver des solutions à ces problèmes en effectuant une recherche sur Google. Cependant, Thunderbird n’est pas à l’origine du problème.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Make sure cookies are allowed in Thunderbird. Are you using a VPN? If so, turn it off when attempting to authenticate. Also make sure no other service is occupying TCP port 80, e.g. a local web server.
